Data.event_text: 4 January  As strong winds and heavy rain continue to batter parts of Scotland, more than 30 flood warnings are issued by SEPA.

links.text: -"Drone shows historic castle teetering over flood water". BBC News. BBC. 4 January 2016. Retrieved 4 January 2016.-

Data.event_text: 6 January  Labour MPs Jonathan Reynolds and Stephen Doughty quit over the sacking of the shadow Europe minister Pat McFadden, after party leader Jeremy Corbyn reshuffles his shadow cabinet and makes controversial changes within his team.

links.text: -"Labour reshuffle: Shadow ministers quit in protest". BBC News. BBC. 6 January 2016. Retrieved 6 January 2016.-

Data.event_text: 1 February  Scientists are given the go-ahead by regulators to genetically modify human embryos which were to be destroyed in seven days.

links.text: -"Scientists get 'gene editing' go-ahead". BBC News. BBC. 1 February 2016. Retrieved 1 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 3 February  The High Court gives permission for Lord Lucan to be declared dead, and for a death certificate to be issued 42 years after his disappearance.

links.text: -"Lord Lucan death certificate granted". BBC News. BBC. 3 February 2016. Retrieved 3 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 8 February  Storm Imogen hits the United Kingdom, causing thousands of power outages and structural damage across the country, along with disruption for many commuters.

links.text: -Finnigan, Lexi (8 February 2016). "Storm Imogen: Record breaking winds amid news an RSPCA worker may have been swept out to sea". The Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 12 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 10 February  Junior doctors walk out in their second recent strike over Saturday working arrangements, causing disruption to medical services.

links.text: -Hindocha, Sumeet (10 February 2016). "Junior doctors strike: Hunt claims 43% of doctors working". The Guardian. Retrieved 12 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 12 February  After many years as print newspapers, it is announced that the UK newspapers The Independent and the Independent on Sunday will cease to print and become online-only at the end of March. Its stablemate, the i, will be sold to Johnston Press.

links.text: -Sweney, Mark (12 February 2016). "Independent and Independent on Sunday print closures confirmed". The Guardian. Retrieved 12 February 2016.-
-"Independent to cease as print edition". BBC News. BBC. 12 February 2016. Retrieved 12 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 February  BBC Three becomes the first UK television network to become online only, having broadcast for its final night after 13 years as a television channel.

links.text: -"BBC Three moves online after final night as TV channel". BBC News. BBC. 16 February 2016. Retrieved 16 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 20 February  David Cameron announces that the United Kingdom will hold a referendum on the United Kingdom's membership of the European Union on 23 June.
21 February  Mayor of London Boris Johnson announces he is to campaign for the UK to leave the European Union.

links.text: -"EU referendum: Time to vote for real change, says Boris Johnson". BBC News. BBC. 22 February 2016. Retrieved 23 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 22 February  The pound hits its lowest level against the dollar, falling down as much as 2.4%, in almost seven years amid concerns about a possible exit from the European Union.

links.text: -"Pound hits lowest level against dollar since 2009". BBC News. BBC. 22 February 2016. Retrieved 22 February 2016.-

Data.event_text: 7 March  Official tourist figures for 2015 show the British Museum remains the most popular attraction in the United Kingdom.

links.text: -"British Museum tops UK attractions for 2015". BBC News. BBC. 7 March 2016. Retrieved 8 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: Four of the gang of "brazen burglars" involved in the Hatton Garden jewellery heist are sentenced to seven years' imprisonment, while a fifth is given six years.

links.text: -"Gang of men sentenced for Hatton Garden raid". BBC News. BBC. 9 March 2016. Retrieved 9 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: Junior doctors strike for the third time over new contracts, with NHS England saying that more than 5,000 operations have been cancelled as a result.

links.text: -"Junior doctors strike for third time over new contract". The Guardian. 9 March 2016. Retrieved 9 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 March  Chancellor George Osborne announces the Budget for 2016 and the year ahead.

links.text: -"Key points of Budget 2015: At-a-glance". BBC News. BBC. 16 March 2016. Retrieved 19 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 18 March  Iain Duncan Smith resigns as Secretary of State for Work and Pensions claiming that he came under pressure from the Treasury to "salami slice" welfare, and voicing his objection to £4bn of planned cuts to disability benefits announced in the Budget. Duncan Smith is succeeded in the post by Stephen Crabb.

links.text: -"Iain Duncan Smith quits over planned disability benefit changes". BBC News. BBC. 18 March 2016. Retrieved 19 March 2016.-
-"Stephen Crabb replaces Iain Duncan Smith". BBC News. BBC. 19 March 2016. Retrieved 19 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 19 March  England win the Six Nations Grand Slam (rugby union) — their first since 2003.

links.text: -Fordyce, Tom (20 December 2016). "England Grand Slam deserved despite imperfections". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 21 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 21 March  Brian Reader, the ringleader in the Hatton Garden jewellery heist, and the last of the gang to be sentenced, is given more than six years in jail.

links.text: -"Hatton Garden heist ringleader jailed". BBC News. BBC. 21 March 2016. Retrieved 21 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 22 March  Transgender fell-runner Lauren Jeska attempts to murder UK Athletics official Ralph Knibbs, stabbing him multiple times in Birmingham. Jeska had feared her records and ability to compete in women's events would be investigated due to the unfair advantage she had from being born male.

links.text: -Fell-runner Lauren Jeska tried to kill British athletics official because she feared the body would revoke her titles over transgender status-

Data.event_text: 23 March  Drivers on London Underground's Piccadilly line go on strike for 24 hours over bullying allegations.

links.text: -"Piccadilly Line tube drivers' strike action starts". BBC News. BBC. 24 March 2016. Retrieved 24 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 28 March  Storm Katie rips through parts of the United Kingdom through the Easter weekend and many parts of the country suffer damage. The storm causes disruption with many flights cancelled or diverted as a result.

links.text: -"Storm Katie 2016: Flights cancelled amid 105mph winds". The Daily Telegraph. 28 March 2016. Retrieved 29 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: 30 March  British steel maker Tata Steel reports that it will sell off its British operations in a move to save money, leaving many thousands of jobs at risk, including those at the large Port Talbot steelworks in Wales.

links.text: -"Tata steel to sell off entire British business". MSN. 30 March 2016. Retrieved 31 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister David Cameron cuts short his spring break to return to the UK for an emergency meeting with ministers on the planned closure of the Tata Steel works.

links.text: -"Tata Steel crisis: Cameron to hold emergency meeting". MSN. 31 March 2016. Retrieved 31 March 2016.-

Data.event_text: This Morning agony aunt Denise Robertson dies aged 83 after a short battle with pancreatic cancer having been diagnosed in early 2016.
Ferrybridge Power Station in West Yorkshire closes after 50 years of electricity generation to make way for a greener future after major fire destroyed part of the plant on 31 July 2014.
1 April  A new National Living Wage comes into force in the United Kingdom, requiring employers to pay all workers over 25 years old at least £7.20 per hour.

links.text: -"National living wage comes into force". BBC News. BBC. 1 April 2016. Retrieved 1 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 6 April  The 2016 Dog Microchipping Legislation comes into force, requiring every dog in England, Scotland and Wales to be micro-chipped if they are over eight weeks old. The law was already introduced in Northern Ireland in 2012.

links.text: -"Dog microchipping becomes compulsory across UK". BBC News. BBC. 6 April 2016. Retrieved 6 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 7 April  A junior doctors' strike over pay disputes enters its second day, with over 5,000 operations and procedures being postponed.

links.text: -"Junior doctors' strike: 'Difficult' second day expected". BBC News. BBC. 7 April 2016. Retrieved 7 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 10 April  English golfer Danny Willett wins the 2016 Masters Tournament, the first time a Briton has won the tournament since Nick Faldo in 1996.

links.text: -"Masters 2016: Danny Willett picks up green jacket at Augusta". BBC Sport. BBC. 11 April 2016. Retrieved 11 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 13 April  Stoke Gifford Parish Council in Gloucestershire votes to charge the weekly Little Stoke Parkrun event for use of its park, becoming the first in the UK to do so. The move is wildly condemned.

links.text: -"Stoke Gifford Parish Council becomes first in UK to charge runners who use public park". The Daily Telegraph. 13 April 2016. Retrieved 13 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 14 April  In the final report following the Shoreham Airshow disaster in August 2015, the Civil Aviation Authority tightens the rules of all future airshows over safety fears.

links.text: -"Air show stunt rules tightened after Shoreham". Sky News. 14 April 2016. Retrieved 14 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 15 April  The European Union membership referendum campaign gets underway in the UK as both sides prepare to persuade voters to decide whether they want to leave or remain in the EU when the referendum takes place in June.

links.text: -"EU referendum campaign gets under way as both sides prepare to bring out the heavyweights". International Business Times. Microsoft (MSN). 15 April 2016. Retrieved 15 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 April  Thousands of people take part in a protest against austerity cuts in central London, including the Shadow Chancellor, John McDonnell.

links.text: -"Austerity protest: Thousands rally in London against cuts". BBC News. BBC. 16 April 2016. Retrieved 17 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: Welsh Footballer Ched Evans has his 2012 conviction for rape quashed by the Court of Appeal. Evans had been wrongly imprisoned for two and half years, a retrial was ordered to take place in October.

links.text: -Ched Evans wins appeal against rape conviction and will now face re-trial-

Data.event_text: Queen Elizabeth II marks her 90th birthday.
A jury at a coroner's court in Warrington declares that the victims of the Hillsborough disaster of 1989 were unlawfully killed.

links.text: -"Hillsborough victims unlawfully killed". Sky News. 26 April 2016. Archived from the original on 9 May 2016. Retrieved 26 April 2016.-
-"Hillsborough victims unlawfully killed". Sky News. 26 April 2016. Archived from the original on 9 May 2016. Retrieved 26 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: Junior doctors go on strike again, this time including those providing emergency care for the first time.

links.text: -"Junior doctors' strike: All-out stoppage 'a bleak day'". BBC News. BBC. 26 April 2016. Retrieved 26 April 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2 May  Leicester City win the Premier League for the first time, having been quoted odds as long as 5000/1 before the start of the season.

links.text: -"Leicester City win Premier League title after Tottenham draw at Chelsea". BBC Sport. BBC. 2 May 2016. Retrieved 3 May 2016.-

Data.event_text: 3 May  Thousands of parents take their children out of school for a day in opposition to the introduction of SAT exams for Year 2 pupils.

links.text: -Mortimer, Caroline (3 May 2016). "SATs strike: Parents to take children out of school in protest over 'stressful' Year 2 exams". The Independent. Independent Print Limited. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 3 May 2016.-

-Mortimer, Caroline (3 May 2016). "SATs strike: Parents to take children out of school in protest over 'stressful' Year 2 exams". The Independent. Independent Print Limited. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 3 May 2016.-

Data.event_text: 5 May  UK local and Police and crime commissioner elections, as well as elections to the Northern Ireland Assembly, Welsh Assembly and Scottish Parliament are held.
7 May  Sadiq Khan is sworn in as mayor of London, succeeding Boris Johnson and becoming London's first Muslim mayor.

links.text: -"Elections: Labour's Sadiq Khan promises a 'better' London". BBC News. BBC. 7 May 2016. Retrieved 7 May 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 May   The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency show a prototype digital driving licence designed to be stored in a digital wallet on a smartphone.

links.text: -"UK developing digital driving licence". BBC News. 16 May 2016.-

Data.event_text: 18 May  The government's planned new laws are set out by the Queen in her annual speech, which include a large overhaul on prison laws and support for a spaceport and driverless cars.

links.text: -"Queen's Speech: Prison shake-up at heart of new laws". BBC News. BBC. 18 May 2016. Retrieved 18 May 2016.-

Data.event_text: 21 May  Manchester United beat Crystal Palace 21 after extra time in the FA Cup final at Wembley Stadium in London. It is the 12th time they have won the competition. Two days later, manager Louis van Gaal is sacked, with José Mourinho set to replace him.[citation needed]

1 June  Archaeologists announce identification of one of the Roman Bloomberg tablets found during 201013 excavations in advance of construction of new Bloomberg London offices in the City of London as the oldest known hand-written document in the United Kingdom, dating back to AD 57.

links.text: -"UK's oldest hand-written document 'at Roman London dig'". BBC News. BBC. 1 June 2016. Retrieved 1 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: 12 June  UEFA threatens to disqualify England from Euro 2016 after "totally unacceptable" violent hooliganism between England and Russia fans during an England-Russia game on 11 June.

links.text: -"Euro 2016: England and Russia given disqualification warning". BBC News. BBC. 12 June 2016. Retrieved 13 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 June  Labour MP Jo Cox dies at Leeds General Infirmary after being shot and stabbed as she prepared to hold a meeting with constituents in Birstall, West Yorkshire.

links.text: -"Jo Cox MP dead after shooting attack". BBC News. BBC. 16 June 2016. Retrieved 18 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: 21 June  Both sides of the referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union take part in the biggest live debate at Wembley Arena on a special edition of Question Time on the BBC. Panelists include former Mayor of London Boris Johnson, for Leave, and his successor Sadiq Khan for Remain.Ballot for the EU referendum

links.text: -"EU referendum: Leave and Remain clash in BBC Great Debate". BBC News. BBC. 21 June 2016. Retrieved 21 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: 23 June  The 2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum is held in the UK and Gibraltar, the first of its kind since the 1975 referendum on the UK's membership of the then European Economic Community.
The United Kingdom votes to leave the European Union in a vote of 51.9% to 48.1%, in a record voting turnout of 72%.

David Cameron resigns as leader of the Conservative Party, announcing he is to step down as Prime Minister by October, claiming "fresh leadership" is needed in the wake of a vote to leave. The 2016 Conservative Party leadership election is launched to find his successor.
London's stock market plunges more than 8% in the wake of the EU referendum result, with the pound falling to its lowest level against the dollar since 1985.

links.text: -"Shares and pound plunge on Leave vote". BBC News. BBC. 24 June 2016. Retrieved 24 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: Several Labour Party shadow cabinet ministers quit, with many more expected, in protest at Jeremy Corbyn's leadership and "lacklustre" referendum campaign. Corbyn issues a statement in response, vowing to stand in any new leadership election and to reshape his shadow cabinet.

links.text: -"EU referendum: Jeremy Corbyn vows to fight for leadership and reshape cabinet". BBC News. BBC. 26 June 2016. Retrieved 26 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: First Minister of Scotland Nicola Sturgeon warns she could persuade the Scottish Parliament to veto the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union.

links.text: -"Nicole Sturgeon says MSPs at Holyrood could veto Brexit". BBC News. BBC. 26 June 2016. Retrieved 26 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne makes a statement to calm the markets, claiming the UK is ready to face the future "from a position of strength" and indicating there won't be an immediate emergency Budget.

links.text: -"Osborne: UK in a position of strength". BBC News. BBC. 27 June 2016. Retrieved 27 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: Ratings agency Standard & Poor's state the referendum result could lead to "a deterioration of the UK's economic performance, including its large financial services sector" as the United Kingdom loses its top AAA credit rating.

links.text: -"UK loses top credit rating from S&P". BBC News. BBC. 27 June 2016. Retrieved 27 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: England are knocked out of UEFA Euro 2016 after a shock 21 defeat to Iceland in the round of 16. England manager Roy Hodgson resigns in the wake of the result.

links.text: -"Euro 2016: Iceland beat England and 'shock the world'". BBC News. BBC. 28 June 2016. Retrieved 30 June 2016.-
-"Euro 2016: Roy Hodgson resigns after England lose to Iceland". BBC News. BBC. 28 June 2016. Retrieved 30 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: A Motion of no confidence by Labour MPs in leader Jeremy Corbyn is passed by a 172 to 40 vote. However, Corbyn reiterates that he will not resign.

links.text: -"Labour MPs pass no-confidence motion in Jeremy Corbyn". BBC News. BBC. 28 June 2016. Retrieved 28 June 2016.-

Data.event_text: Stephen Crabb becomes the first MP to announce their candidacy in the 2016 Conservative Party leadership election.

30 June  Michael Gove, Theresa May, Andrea Leadsom and Liam Fox announce their candidacies for leadership of the Conservative Party and subsequently Prime Minister. Boris Johnson, a front runner for the job according to political analysts, surprisingly declares his intentions not to campaign.

links.text: -"Michael Gove and Theresa May enter Conservative race". BBC News. BBC. 30 June 2016. Retrieved 30 June 2016.-
-"Boris Johnson rules himself out of Conservative leader race". BBC News. BBC. 30 June 2016. Retrieved 4 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: A two-minute silence is observed at 7.28 a.m. throughout the United Kingdom to commemorate the centenary of the Battle of the Somme. The art event We're Here Because We're Here is staged across the U.K. by Jeremy Deller to mark the same event.

links.text: -"Battle of the Somme – Royals at Somme centenary commemoration". BBC News. BBC. 1 July 2016. Retrieved 1 July 2016.-
-Higgins, Charlotte (1 July 2016). "#Wearehere: Somme tribute revealed as Jeremy Deller work". The Guardian. Retrieved 1 January 2017.-

Data.event_text: Wales qualify for the semi-final of Euro 2016 after beating Belgium 31, the team's most significant victory since 1958.

links.text: -"Wales 3–1 Belgium". BBC Sport. 1 July 2016. Retrieved 2 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: 4 July  UK Independence Party leader Nigel Farage resigns, saying his "political ambition had been achieved" with the UK voting to leave the European Union.

links.text: -"UKIP leader Nigel Farage stands down". BBC News. BBC. 4 July 2016. Retrieved 4 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: 6 July  The Chilcot Inquiry report into the Iraq War is released, more than seven years after the inquiry was first announced, showing that the UK went to war before peaceful options were exhausted, that military action was not the "last resort", ill-prepared troops were sent into battle with inadequate plans for the aftermath, and that the threat from Saddam Hussein was overstated; ultimately rejecting former Prime Minister Tony Blair's case for the 2003 invasion.

links.text: -"Chilcot report: Tony Blair's Iraq War case not justified". BBC News. BBC. 6 July 2016. Retrieved 6 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: 8 July  Women are now permitted to serve in close combat roles in the British armed services.

links.text: -"Ban on women in ground close combat roles lifted". Ministry of Defence. 8 July 2016. Retrieved 26 June 2017.-

Data.event_text: 10 July  Angela Eagle announces she will challenge Jeremy Corbyn for leadership of the Labour Party, triggering a leadership election.New Prime Minister and Conservative leader Theresa May

links.text: -"Angela Eagle launches leader bid 'to heal Labour'". BBC News. BBC. 10 July 2016. Retrieved 19 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: Andy Murray defeated Milos Raonic of Canada in straight sets for his 2nd Men Singles title at Wimbledon 2016. Andy Murray became the first British man since Fred Perry in 1935 to win the Wimbledon Championships multiple times.

links.text: -"Andy Murray wins Wimbledon by beating Milos Raonic". BBC Sport.-

Data.event_text: 11 July  Theresa May is announced as the Conservative Party leader, and Prime Minister-designate, after Andrea Leadsom withdraws from the leadership election.
David Cameron officially tenders his resignation as Prime Minister to the Queen, and is succeeded by his former Home Secretary Theresa May.

Theresa May begins to announce her cabinet, with Philip Hammond as the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Amber Rudd as Home Secretary, Boris Johnson as Foreign Secretary, and David Davis appointed in the new Exiting the European Union Secretary post.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson made foreign secretary by Theresa May". BBC News. BBC. 13 July 2016. Retrieved 13 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: Owen Smith announces he will also contest the 2016 Labour Party leadership election.
18 July  MPs vote to back the renewal of the UK's Trident nuclear weapons programme, in a vote of 472 to 117.

links.text: -"MPs vote to renew Trident weapons system". BBC News. BBC. 18 July 2016. Retrieved 19 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: 19 July  Angela Eagle withdraws from the 2016 Labour Party leadership election, leaving Owen Smith to challenge Jeremy Corbyn for the leadership in a head-to-head race.
24 July  Chris Froome wins the Tour de France for the second year running and third time overall. Froome's victory means that a British rider has won four of the last five editions of the race.

links.text: -"Tour de France 2016: Chris Froome completes third race victory". 24 July 2016. Retrieved 26 July 2016.-

Data.event_text: 28 July  EDF approves investment in the first new nuclear power plant to be built in the UK in 20 years at Hinkley Point, Somerset; however, the government delay a final decision, calling for it to be reviewed by the autumn.

links.text: -"Hinkley Point nuclear plant delay 'bonkers' says union". BBC News. BBC. 29 July 2016. Retrieved 2 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 1 August  Permission is given to enlarge the Yorkshire Dales and Lake District National Parks in northern England.

links.text: -"Yorkshire Dales and Lake District National Parks extend". BBC News. 1 August 2016. Retrieved 6 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 4 August  The Bank of England cuts interest rates from 0.5% to 0.25%  a record low and the first cut since 2009.

links.text: -"UK interest rates cut to 0.25%". BBC News. 4 August 2016. Retrieved 4 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 8 August  A five-day strike by workers on Southern Rail begins, disrupting train services between London, Surrey and Sussex, the longest rail strike in the United Kingdom since 1968.

links.text: -"Southern rail strike: Five-day walkout begins". BBC News. 8 August 2016. Retrieved 8 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 12 August  Mumin Sahin and Emin Ozmen are jailed for a total of 42 years for their part in the UK's largest ever drugs haul, in which 3.2 tonnes of cocaine worth £512 million was seized from a vessel in the North Sea.

links.text: -"Two men jailed for smuggling £512m of cocaine in tug boat". BBC News. 12 August 2016. Retrieved 12 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: The radical Islamic cleric Anjem Choudary and his assistant Mohammed Mizahnur Rahman are found guilty at the Old Bailey of inviting support for a proscribed terrorist organisation, Islamic State.

links.text: -"Radical cleric Anjem Choudary guilty of inviting IS support". BBC News. 16 August 2016. Retrieved 16 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: The world's largest ever wind farm, consisting of 300 turbines producing 1.8 gigawatts of clean energy, is approved for construction off the Yorkshire coast.

links.text: -"World's largest ever windfarm to be built off Yorkshire coast". The Independent. 16 August 2016. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 16 August 2016.-
-"World's largest ever windfarm to be built off Yorkshire coast". The Independent. 16 August 2016. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 16 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 17 August  The Airlander 10 hybrid airship, the world's largest aircraft at 92 m (302 ft) in length and 38,000 m3 (1,300,000 cu ft) in volume, has its maiden civilian flight in Bedfordshire.

links.text: -"Airlander 10: Maiden flight at last for 'longest' aircraft". BBC. 17 August 2016. Retrieved 17 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 21 August  Team GB finish competing at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. They finish second in the medal table, with 27 golds, 23 silvers, and 17 bronze medals; their best Olympic result in over a century.

links.text: -"Rio Olympics 2016: Team GB beat China to finish second in the medal table". BBC Sport. 21 August 2016. Retrieved 21 August 2016.-

Data.event_text: 1 September  The Francis Crick Institute, Europe's largest biomedical research facility, opens in London.

links.text: -"The Crick: Europe's biggest biomedical lab opens". BBC. 1 September 2016. Retrieved 10 September 2016.-
-"Science begins in the new Francis Crick Institute building". The Francis Crick Institute. 1 September 2016. Retrieved 10 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2 September  Nicholas Chamberlain, the Bishop of Grantham becomes the first Church of England bishop to openly declare he is gay and in a relationship.

links.text: -"CofE Bishop Nicholas Chamberlain reveals he is in gay relationship". BBC. 2 September 2016. Retrieved 2 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: 12 September  Former Prime Minister David Cameron resigns from the House of Commons, triggering the 2016 Witney by-election.

links.text: -"David Cameron quits as Conservative MP for Witney". BBC. 12 September 2016. Retrieved 13 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: The first Bank of England polymer banknote enters circulation. (Northern Bank in Northern Ireland had previously issued a polymer £5 note, but that was not legal tender in the rest of the UK).

links.text: -"New £5 note: Bank of England's first polymer banknote enters circulation". The Independent. 13 September 2016. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 13 September 2016.-
-"New £5 note: Bank of England's first polymer banknote enters circulation". The Independent. 13 September 2016. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 13 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: The UK experiences its hottest September day since 1911, with 34.4 °C recorded in Gravesend, Kent.

links.text: -"Highest September temperature since 1911 as 34.4C recorded". BBC. 13 September 2016. Retrieved 13 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: 15 September  The government approves the Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, which will cost £18bn, and says it will introduce "new safeguards" to future projects.

links.text: -"Hinkley Point: UK approves nuclear plant deal". BBC. 15 September 2016. Retrieved 15 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: Flash flooding hits parts of England as thunderstorms dump almost half a month's rainfall in some areas overnight.

links.text: -"Post-heatwave storm brings flash floods causing widespread disruption". BBC. 16 September 2016. Retrieved 16 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: Diane James is elected the new leader of UKIP.

links.text: -"Diane James becomes UKIP leader". BBC. 16 September 2016. Retrieved 16 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: 24 September  Jeremy Corbyn is re-elected as leader of the Labour Party following an unsuccessful challenge by Owen Smith.

links.text: -"Labour leadership: Jeremy Corbyn defeats Owen Smith". BBC News. BBC. 24 September 2016. Retrieved 24 September 2016.-

Data.event_text: 5 October  Diane James quits as leader of UKIP after only 18 days in the post.

links.text: -"UKIP's Diane James quits as leader after 18 days". Sky News. 5 October 2016. Retrieved 5 October 2016.-

Data.event_text: 6 October  Communities Secretary Sajid Javid approves plans for fracking at Cuadrilla's Preston New Road site in Lancashire, overturning an earlier decision by the local council.

links.text: -"Fracking in Lancashire given go-ahead by government". BBC News. 6 October 2016. Retrieved 6 October 2016.-

Data.event_text: 12 October  Welsh footballer Ched Evans is cleared of rape in a retrial, having previously been wrongfully convicted for the offence, serving two and half years in prison.

links.text: -"Ched Evans cleared of rape in retrial".-

Data.event_text: 25 October  The government approves a third runway at Heathrow Airport. Zac Goldsmith MP for Richmond Park resigns in protest.

links.text: -"Third runway at Heathrow cleared for takeoff by ministers". BBC News. 25 October 2016. Retrieved 25 October 2016.-
-"Zac Goldsmith immediately quits as Tory MP for Richmond Park in protest over Heathrow expansion". The Telegraph. 25 October 2016. Retrieved 25 October 2016.-

Data.event_text: 2 November  The High Court in London rules in favour of ClientEarth in their case against the government regarding dangerous levels of air pollution in the UK.

links.text: -"Green group wins in air pollution court battle". BBC News. 2 November 2016. Retrieved 2 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: 5 November  The British tennis player Andy Murray becomes ATP world number one, the first British player of either sex to reach number one in tennis rankings in the modern era.

links.text: -"Andy Murray becomes world number one after Raonic withdraws from Paris Masters". BBC Sport. 5 November 2016. Retrieved 5 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: 9 November  2016 Croydon tram derailment Seven people die and 61 are injured when a tram derails close to Sandilands tram stop in Croydon. London.

links.text: -"Croydon tram crash: TfL to admit to failings over fatal derailment". BBC News. 10 June 2022. Retrieved 10 June 2022.-

Data.event_text: The British Medical Journal backs the legalisation of drugs for the first time, arguing that the "War on Drugs" has failed.

links.text: -"British Medical Journal advocates legalisation of drugs for first time". London Evening Standard. 15 November 2016. Retrieved 15 November 2016.-
-"The war on drugs has failed and doctors should lead calls for change, says The BMJ" (PDF). BMJ. 15 November 2016. Retrieved 15 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: The second phase of the high-speed rail line HS2 is confirmed by the government, with lines running from Crewe to Manchester and the West Midlands to Leeds.

links.text: -"HS2: North West and Yorkshire routes confirmed". BBC News. 15 November 2016. Retrieved 15 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: 17 November  Tornadoes affect parts of The Midlands and Wales, causing some damage.

links.text: -"Tornadoes hit Wales and the Midlands". BBC News. 17 November 2016. Retrieved 17 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor Philip Hammond delivers the Autumn Statement to Parliament, announced to be the final such Statement, being replaced by a full Budget in 2017.

links.text: -"Autumn Statement 2016". Government of the United Kingdom. Retrieved 24 December 2016.-
-Jones, Stephen (23 November 2016). "Chancellor stuns MPs by revealing it's his first and last Autumn Statement". mirror. Retrieved 24 December 2016.-
-"Autumn Statement – Hansard Online". Parliament of the United Kingdom. Retrieved 24 December 2016.-

Data.event_text: Thomas Mair was found guilty of the murder of Jo Cox, who was serving as Member of Parliament (MP) for Batley and Spen at the time of her death. He was sentenced to life imprisonment with a whole life order and Justice Wilkie said Mair's actions "betrayed the quintessence of our country".

links.text: -"Jo Cox murder: Judge's sentencing remarks to Thomas Mair". BBC News. 23 November 2016. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-

Data.event_text: 25 November  Stephen Port was sentenced to life imprisonment with a whole life order for the four murders committed between June 2014 to September 2015.

links.text: -"Serial killer Stephen Port jailed for rape drug murders". BBC News. 25 November 2016. Retrieved 23 March 2025.-

Data.event_text: 28 November  Paul Nuttall is elected as UKIP's new leader.

links.text: -"Paul Nuttall elected as UKIP leader". BBC News. 28 November 2016. Retrieved 29 November 2016.-

Data.event_text: 29 November The Investigatory Powers Bill receives Royal assent.

links.text: -"Investigatory Powers Act 2016 — UK Parliament". Parliament of the United Kingdom. Retrieved 24 December 2016.-

Data.event_text: 7 December  HMS Illustrious, the last Invincible-class aircraft carrier, makes its final voyage out of Portsmouth Harbour to a ship recycling company in Turkey.

links.text: -"Former aircraft carrier HMS Illustrious sails out of Portsmouth". BBC News. 7 December 2016. Retrieved 7 December 2016.-

Data.event_text: 16 December  A riot occurs at HMP Birmingham, described as the worst since the Strangeways prison riot and protest of 1990. Authorities regain control of all four wings after more than 12 hours of disorder involving 600 inmates.

links.text: -"HMP Birmingham riot: Officers regain control of prison". BBC News. 17 December 2016. Retrieved 17 December 2016.-
